This metric measures the proportion of the variance in the dependent variable that can be explained by the independent variables in the model. 

The R-cv^2 values obtained in the study ranged from 0.40 to 0.67 for above-ground biomass estimation and from 0.47 to 0.48 for plant N concentration estimation. These values indicate that the models were able to explain between 40% and 67% of the variance in above-ground biomass and between 47% and 48% of the variance in plant N concentration using the available predictors and sensor data.

While these R-cv^2 values provide an indication of the model performance, it is important to note that they do not capture the entire picture. Other metrics such as root mean square error (RMSE) and relative root mean square error (rRMSE) were also used to assess the accuracy and precision of the models. These metrics provide additional information about the magnitude of errors and the relative performance of the models.

instruction: Can the use of low-cost UAS-based multispectral sensors and non-linear machine learning algorithms be considered superior to traditional methods for estimating above-ground biomass and plant N concentration in grasslands, based on the findings of the related study?
Output: Yes.Based on the findings of the related study, the use of low-cost UAS-based multispectral sensors and non-linear machine learning algorithms can be considered superior to traditional methods for estimating above-ground biomass and plant N concentration in grasslands. The study compared different sensors (Parrot Sequoia, SEQ; MicaSense RedEdge-M, REM), statistical models (linear model; random forests, RFs; gradient-boosting machines, GBMs), and predictor sets (raw reflectance, vegetation indices, and canopy height). The non-linear machine learning algorithms showed acceptable regression performance for all sensor-predictor set combinations, with average R-cv(2) of 0.48 for above-ground biomass and 0.40 for plant N concentration estimation. The optimal combination of sensors, machine learning algorithms, and predictor sets notably improved the model performance. The best model performance for above-ground biomass estimation was achieved with an RF model using all predictors and REM sensor data, while for plant N concentration, the best model was a combination of an RF model with all predictors and SEQ sensor data. Additionally, the addition of canopy height information significantly improved the above-ground biomass models. Therefore, the use of low-cost UAS-based multispectral sensors and non-linear machine learning algorithms can be considered superior.
